title: What are the advantages and disadvantages of the Devanagari script? - Quora

response.answer_text: Advantages: The most versatile script in India. See below (Source: Wikipedia) for the number of languages that can be written in this script. It is fully phonetic (like the IPA). Unlike English and French, if you read a word written in this script you cannot possibly mispronounce it. You might get only the accent wrong.  Though Gujarati is mentioned in the list above, it is written in a slightly modified form of the Devanagari script. The consonants are rounded off at the corners and the short horizontal line at the top is omitted in Gujarati. Only the vowels are different. More than 600 million people all over the Indian subcontinent use this script and many of those who use Dravidian scripts can read Devanagari too. It is the most ubiquitous script in India. Disadvantages: For decades, typing was a hassle for most of us. The keyboard is complex and requires special training. Unlike English and the European languages, experts were needed to type in this language. This made Devanagari a late adapter in today’s computer and smart phone era and it lagged behind English. For years Indians typing / messaging in Indian regional languages used the imperfect Roman script to send out messages in local languages. Even now many do it but many have now reverted to the better and more accurate Devanagari script. However with phonetic transliteration, Devanagari has now caught up. We now type the 26 Roman characters available on any QWERTY keyboard and it takes just a few minutes of training and a week’s practice to be able to type facilely in Devanagari using Qwerty keyboard. The software does the conversion in the background. Software like GBoard when used with Voice dictation makes typing in Devanagari a breeze. You talk. Gboard types it almost flawlessly. Unlike in English where GBoard hears ‘By’ and does not know if it’s By, or buy, or bye and when it hears ‘to’ Gboard does not know if that is “to”, or “too” or “two” or “2”, Hindi / Devanagari voice typing is straightforward and the output by GBoard requires very little editing. I use it extensively on my smartphone to type out my Quora answers in Hindi using Devanagari. Tailpiece: Added for fun. Using Gboard, I had dictated “ I am meeting ….” Gboard typed “I am eating….” This does not happen in Devanagari! — Edited to add: I am thankful to Mahesh Gujjar who told me about this site for speech to text conversion in a variety of languages. I tried it in English and Hindi and it worked perfectly for me. Speech to Text Online Notepad. Free —

Advantages Quasi-phoneticity in usage: All languages incorporating Devanagari as their script use it phonetically although there are some variations that essentially prevent it from being completely phonetic across all its languages. The almost phoneticity helps tremendously in speech-to-text transliterations, preventing ambiguity as long as the speaker’s own pronunciation and accent is correct. To incorporate variations, some speech-to-text transliterators allow users to choose language first. [ The common variations in pronunciations are as follows: ऐ and औ can be spoken in 2 variations — अए (aē) and अओ (aō) i.e. as their constituent vowels, or as a slightly longer form of ‘a’ in ‘max’ and ‘o’ in ‘often’. Both would be considered correct in modern usage.ऋ (r̥) is spoken as ‘ri’ in Hindi while as ‘ru’ in Marathi and Konkaniज्ञ (jña) is spoken as ‘gya’ in Hindi and ‘dnya’ in Marathi.] Usage in multiple languages: Devanagari is used as primary or one of the scripts in multiple languages across northern India, western India and Nepal. This implies a large set of languages can be read (although not necessarily) understood by a person who can read Devanagari. The languages include Sanskr̥ta (historically, primary script was Brahmi), Hindi (also written in Arabic script), Nepali, Apabhramsha, Konkani, Awadhi, Bhojpuri, Maithili, Braj Bhasha, Sindhi, Haryanvi, Newar, Kashmiri, Magadhi/Magahi, Sadri etc. Devanagari is also related to Nandinagari script used in southern India, and therefore, a person who can read Devanagari may also be able to read Nandinagari. Devanagari letters in Chandas font (Source: File:Chandas typeface specimen.svg - Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Chandas_typeface_specimen.svg))  Chart of Nandinagari (Source: File:Nandinagari script.png - Wikipedia)  Chart showing similarities in Indic scripts (Source: File:Examples.of.complex.text.rendering.svg - Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Examples.of.complex.text.rendering.svg))   Disadvantages Need of relatively larger symbol set: Since almost all languages using Devanagari use it phonetically, it requires a larger symbol set to accommodate them. Devanagari keyboards need to accommodate following symbols: The 13 vowels and 31 consonants found in Sanskr̥t. These are usually common across languages that use Devanagari.ॲ and ऑ found in Konkani and Marathi, as well as ऍ, ऎ and ऒळ found in Odiya and some other languagesॡ — essentially a graphic convention included among the vowels in order to maintain the symmetry of short–long pairs of letters (with ऌ).Diacritic marks found in Vedic languageVarious mātrās i.e. vowel notations over consonantsNotations for half-consonants, including 3 for R (र) — curved upward slash (eg. र्व rva, र्वा rvā), single downward slash (eg. क्र ग्र भ्र ब्र) and double downward slash (eg. ट्र ṭra ठ्र ṭhra ड्र ḍra ढ्र ḍhra)— when it is combined with a consonant.Compound consonants that differ markedly from constituent consonant symbols — क्ष (क् + ष), ज्ञ (ज् + ञ) and त्र (त् + र​)​The symbol halant (्) that marks a consonant without any vowel notation (since every consonant inherently has a vowel in Devanagari)The symbol visarga (ः) that represents a slight ‘h’ sound at the end of the letter is written of.The nasal symbols anunāsika (ँ) and anusvāra (ं)The symbol avagraha (ऽ)The stop symbols — । (existent in almost Devanagari using languages) and ॥ (existent only in Sanskr̥ta)The subscript dot (़) called Nuqta, that changes the pronunciation of a consonantThe subscript bar ( ॒) to accommodate implosives found in Sindhi and Saraiki.Additionally, a Devanagari keyboard may accommodate the symbol Om (ॐ) and the symbols for numbers.Speech to text transliterations: Since most languages incorporating Devanagari as their script use it phonetically, text to speech transliterations are relatively easier, but there are a few peculiar challenges, even if incorrect accents and mispronunciations are not taken into account. Diphthongs present a challenge — In Sanskr̥ta, diphthongs are merely single character vowels (ए ऐ ओ औ) but Hindi and few other languages allow consecutive vowels without need to conjoin them eg. आइए (come), something not allowed in Sanskr̥ta.ऐ and औ can be spoken in 2 variations — अए (aē) and अओ (aō) i.e. as their constituent vowels, or as a slightly longer form of ‘a’ in ‘max’ and ‘o’ in ‘often’. Both would be considered correct in modern usage. (Stated previously) Now, how to transliterate from speech to text?Avagraha (ऽ) — This symbols presents challenge specific to language. In Sanskr̥ta, it is used for prodelision, and should be represented in Latin as apostrophe between letters of a word eg शिवोऽहम् → Śivo’ham. In Hindi, the usage is for prolonging of vowels eg. माँऽऽऽ! → ‘Mãããã!
